Olmert is appointed Minister of Finance.
Is named Acting Prime Minister after Sharon suffers a stroke.
The Kadima party wins the largest number of parliamentary seats, ensuring that Olmert will be the next Prime Minister.
Is sworn in as the 12th Prime Minister of Israel.
Addresses a joint meeting of the US Congress.
Olmert announces he will resign as prime minister when Kadima elects a new chairman.
Tzipi Livni
Resigns shortly after police recommend charges in corruption probes.
Is indicted on charges including fraud and breach of trust in dual scandals called the Talansky affair and the Rishon Tours affair.
The trial begins in September 2009.
While on trial for fraud and breach of trust, Olmert is indicted for bribery in a separate case.
Olmert's trial ends after almost three years.
He is found guilty of breach of trust and acquitted on two corruption charges.
He receives a one year suspended jail sentence and is ordered to pay a fine of 75,000 shekels (about $19,000).
Is convicted of bribery charges in a trial related to the Holyland Affair.
The Supreme Court orders a retrial in the Rishon Tours/Talansky case, as new evidence emerges, enabling prosecutors to challenge Olmert's acquittals on corruption charges in 2012.
Olmert is convicted of fraud and breach of trust in the retrial of the Rishon Tours/Talansky case.
His total prison sentence for the Talansky/Rishon Tours case and the Holyland Affair is 27 months.
Olmert arrives at prison.
Olmert is released after serving 16 months, two-thirds of his original 27-month prison term.
